headline.main-hed: GM Ignored Earlier Warning on Cars Stalling

alt-summary-body.p: Lawmakers offered a fresh example of General Motors ignoring an employee's warning in 2005 of "serious safety problem" with the ignition switch on the 2006 Impala that could lead to a "big recall" as new round of hearings got underway in Washington.

Lawmakers offered a fresh example of General Motors ignoring an employee's warning in 2005 of "serious safety problem" with the ignition switch on the 2006 Impala that could lead to a "big recall" for unexpected stalling as new round of hearings got underway in Washington.

headline.main-hed: GM Officials Ignored Alert on Car Stalling
headline.deck: Switch Engineer, Others Were Sent 2005 Warning Over Bump Disabling Engine

article-body.byline: By Jeff Bennett and Siobhan Hughes

media.media-caption: General Motors CEO Mary Barra speaks to Congress about changes to be implemented at GM after a troubled recall on a defective ignition switch linked to at least 13 deaths since 2002. Photo: Getty

article-body.p: WASHINGTON—A General Motors Co. employee warned in 2005 that the auto maker had a "serious safety problem" with the design of ignition switches used on the 2006 Impala that could lead to a "big recall," but the company didn't recall the vehicles until early this week.

The new evidence that GM employees ignored warnings about defects in the years leading up to the company's 2009 bankruptcy came as lawmakers on the House panel questioned GM Chief Executive Mary Barra and former U.S. prosecutor Anton Valukas on whether the car maker deliberately covered up knowledge of safety defects to avoid regulatory scrutiny and deflect lawsuits.

The employee, Laura J. Andres, told GM engineers in 2005 that the Chevrolet Impala she was driving shut off after she went over a bump in the road. In a subsequent August 2005 email she warned that the problem appeared to be the design of the Impala's ignition switch, and noted a GM technician who looked at her car said other employees had complained about a similar problem with the Pontiac Solstice—a small car that shared components with the 2005 Chevrolet Cobalt and other compact vehicles now known to possess a deadly defect.

Ms. Andres urged that engineers consider changing the part. "I think this is a serious safety problem, especially if this switch is on multiple programs," Ms. Andres wrote in one of a chain of emails released by a House panel on Wednesday. "I'm thinking big recall. I was driving 45 mph when I hit the pothole and the car shut off, and I had a car driving behind me that swerved around me. I don't like to imagine a customer driving their kids in the back seat, on I-75, and hitting a pothole, in rush hour traffic."

media.media-caption: GM CEO Mary Barra being sworn in during Wednesday's hearing.

article-body.p: A GM spokesman said Ms. Andres wouldn't comment on her emails.

One of the workers on the email chain was former GM ignition-switch engineer Raymond DeGiorgio, who is among 15 employees GM dismissed earlier this month for failing to act on evidence that stalls caused by faulty ignition switches in Cobalts and Saturn Ions had preceded fatal crashes.

GM has said its engineers and managers at the time didn't consider stalling a safety problem, which is why they rejected fixes for the switches because they cost too much, or risked slowing the launches of new models. Ms. Andres' warning was copied to 11 other employees. GM declined to elaborate on the responsibilities of the individuals copied.
"We encourage our employees to speak up for safety, and an issue like the one described in the memo is something that today we would respond to immediately," the company said in a statement.

link.highlight: U.S. Takes a Look at Chrysler, Jeep Ignition Troubles
Gripes About New Cars Tick Higher

highlight.link: GM Recalls More Cars Over Ignition Switch Issues
Regulator Limits Access to Car Alerts

article-body.p: Lawmakers pressed Ms. Barra to explain how she will change GM to assure that future safety problems aren't ignored, and challenged the company's portrayal of the delayed recalls as the result of bureaucratic buck-passing and incompetence.

"I remain unconvinced there wasn't an effort to 'cover up' bad decisions to avoid liability," said Rep. Tim Murphy (R., Pa.), the panel's chairman. It is probing why GM waited a decade to recall cars with a deadly safety defect involving Chevrolet Cobalts, Saturn Ions and other compact cars. Other lawmakers cited parts of an internal report that suggested GM managers had feared they could lose their jobs by raising safety concerns.

The internal report quotes GM quality manager Steven Oakley as saying that he was "reluctant to push hard on safety issues because of his perception that his predecessor had been pushed out of his job for doing just that."

Ms. Barra said Mr. Oakley is still employed by GM, and is raising new safety concerns. "We are taking it very seriously," she said. Ms. Barra launched a "Speak Up for Safety Program" and plans to reward employees for raising concerns about vehicle safety. "I am personally getting information from employees," she said.

media.media-caption: Anton Valukas, who led GM's probe, testified before a House panel.

article-body.p: Ms. Barra has vowed to upend the corporate culture for what she has described as a "pattern of incompetence and neglect."
Asked after the hearing about Ms. Andres' emails, Ms. Barra said they referred to "a different situation" from the Cobalt-Ion recall. Now, she said, "we consider stalls to be a safety issue."

Ms. Barra and other GM officials portrayed the weight that customers put on key chains as an industrywide safety issue, not just a GM engineering issue. They pointed to NHTSA's move on Wednesday to investigate 1.2 million Chrysler and Jeep vehicles for possible ignition switch problems.
"I have seen incredible things on key chains," Ms. Barra told lawmakers. "It is something that needs to be addressed more broadly across the industry."

media.media-caption: General Motors CEO Mary Barra faced a House panel on decisions over its ignition switch recalls. Some expressed skepticism over the company's handling of the recall as well as its internal culture. Michael Robinson from CLS Strategies joins Tanya Rivero to discuss. Photo: Getty

article-body.p: NHTSA, however, has focused on the design of switches. Auto makers are moving away from ignition switches that use keys that twist a lock on the steering column. Many new vehicles come with push button start systems that allow customers to keep keys in their purse or pocket.

Ms. Barra's testimony "raised more questions than it answered," U.S. Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) said in a statement. "GM needs a safety reset. After three Congressional hearings, an extensive internal report, and a plethora of press, GM still has no clear answers as to why the concealment of the ignition defect was allowed to occur and persist for so long."

Other lawmakers questioned Ms. Barra about GM's plans to set up a fund managed by compensation expert Kenneth Feinberg to pay victims of crashes involving some 2.6 million Cobalts, Ions and related vehicles with defective ignition switches.

The question of liability is at the heart of a fight between plaintiffs' lawyers and GM. The auto maker has argued that it is shielded from liability for claims stemming from ignition-switch problems that occurred before its 2009 bankruptcy. Lawyers for the families of people who died while driving the Chevrolet Cobalt and other vehicles say that GM can't protect itself from claims because engineers and others at GM knew about the ignition-switch problem before the bankruptcy but failed to say anything.

Rep. Diana DeGette (D., Colo.), the top Democrat on the subcommittee, added that the report "does not answer all the key questions," saying that the report "singles out many individuals at GM who made poor decisions or failed to act, but it doesn't identify one individual in positions of high leadership who was responsible for these systemic failures."
Rep. DeGette also said that while the report absolved previous chief executives, the board and Ms. Barra from knowing about the problems, "that is nothing to be proud about."

House Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton (R., Mich.) said the investigation will continue, and indicated that there could be another hearing, this one focused on why regulators at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration didn't act sooner to demand that GM recall the Cobalt and other small cars with defective ignition switches.
Write to Jeff Bennett at jeff.bennett@wsj.com and Siobhan Hughes at siobhan.hughes@wsj.com
